question: Question_01_(e)
statement:
\textbf{Sequences and Series: Short Answer Problems - Determine whether
the following sequences and series converge (full marks for correct
answer with justification; work must be shown for partial marks)}

Does the series $\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n(\ln n)}$ converge?
sols:
Let $f(x) = \frac{1}{x\ln x}$. Since this series is continuous, positive
and decreasing on $[2,\infty)$, we may apply the integral test to see
that the series converges or diverges based on if the following integral
converges or diverges:

$\displaystyle \int_{2}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x\ln x}$

To compute this, we have that
$\displaystyle \int_{2}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x\ln x} = \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_{2}^{b}\frac{1}{x\ln x}$

Let $\displaystyle u = \ln x$ so $\displaystyle du = \frac{dx}{x}$ and
$\displaystyle u(2) = \ln(2)$ and $\displaystyle u(b) = \ln(b)$. This
gives

\begin{align*}
 \displaystyle \int_{2}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x\ln x} &=  \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_{2}^{b}\frac{1}{x\ln x} \\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty}  \int_{\ln(2)}^{\ln(b)}\frac{du}{u} \\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \ln|u| \left.\right|_{\ln(2)}^{\ln(b)} \\
&= \lim_{ b \to \infty} \ln|\ln(b)| - \ln|\ln(2)|\end{align*}

As this last limit diverges since $\displaystyle \ln|\ln(b)|$ tends to
infinity as \emph{b} tends to infinity, we have that the series
diverges.

\textbf{NOTE: Compare this to the previous question. Even though the
sequence of terms converges to zero, the integral here still diverges!}
hints: Which convergence tests work well with polynomials and logarithms?
The integral test will work well here.
